text:
Rise of young children calling helplines for bedtime stories as parents TOO DRUNK Rise of young children calling helplines for bedtime stories as parents TOO DRUNK CHILDREN as young as five are calling a helpline to be read bedtime stories because their alcoholic parents are too drunk to tuck them in at night. PUBLISHED: PUBLISHED: 00:01, Sun, Feb 19, 2017 GETTY Young children living with drunk parents are relying on helplines to read them a bed time story 
Counsellors are being called so regularly by some children that they keep a stack of their favourite books by their telephones. 
Hilary Henriques, chief executive of the National Association for Children of Alcoholics, which received 32,000 calls and emails from children last year, said the practice had been going on for almost a decade. Related articles Couple call 999 to ask police to BABYSIT son so they can go on holiday 
She said: “The children like to hear a made-up story because this helps to get across the message that things can be different from the life they live at the moment, which is really the cornerstone of what we do – keep hope alive.” 
Speaking to mark National Children of Alcoholics Week, she added: “The Horrid Henry books are really popular, along with Roald Dahl. 
“Another popular book is Disney’s Treasury Of Children’s Classics which is used a lot and was given to us by a little girl back in 2007.” GETTY Counsellors keep a stack of children's favourite books next to their phones as calls are so regular The children like to hear a made-up story because this helps to get across the message that things can be different from the life they live at the moment. Hilary Henriques, chief executive of NACOA 
One Christmas Day, Hilary took a call from a seven-year-old girl called Lucy who spent 47 minutes hiding from her alcoholic parents under a bed to listen to a bedtime story. 
Cold and crying, having received no presents from Father Christmas, she asked for a story about her imaginary friend, a dog called Bruce. 
Hilary said: “The best we can do is to stay with her under the bed. 
“She needs to know she is not alone, she is not responsible for her parents’ drinking or behaviour and there are people who care and who she can trust.” NACOA The National Association for Children of Alcoholics line received 32,000 calls and emails in 2016 
Another girl, five-year-old Orla, called the charity worried her alcoholic drugaddicted mother, who had locked herself in the bathroom overnight, was dead. 
Over the course of two hours the counsellor and two colleagues were able to talk the little girl through the process of calling an ambulance. 
She put Disney stickers on her window to alert the paramedics but when they arrived with the police and forced open the bathroom door they discovered her mother’s cold and lifeless body. 
Orla told the helpline her mother’s “nose and mouth were blue and that she was not breathing” and paramedics could do nothing to save her life. GETTY The helpline have also helped children call an ambulance for their passed out drunken parents 
Last week, an All-Party Parliamentary Group led by Labour MPs Liam Byrne and Caroline Flint launched a manifesto for change calling on the Government to do more for Britain’s 2.5 million children who live with a hard-drinking parent. 
Both have spoken of their struggles growing up as the children of alcoholics. 
Mr Byrne’s father Dermot died in 2015 after battling with drink for decades. 
Ms Flint’s mother Wendy died from liver damage in 1990, aged just 45. The Archbishop of Canterbury, whose father Gavin Welby was also an alcoholic, has thrown his weight behind the cause. 
And actresses Geraldine James and Cherie Lunghi, with George Best’s son Calum, have also offered their support. 
Research shows children of alcoholics are four times more likely to become heavy drinkers, three times more likely to consider suicide and five times more likely to develop eating disorders. 
Despite this, none of the 138 local authorities who were asked what support they provided to the children of alcoholics actually had a strategy. Unbelievable facts about alcohol
